title: Ernesto projected to miss Halifax , brush past Newfoundland
message:
In what is appearing to look like a near-miss, Hurricane Ernesto’s track is bending to curve southeast of Halifax late tomorrow and brush past the south-facing coasts of Newfoundland and Labrador late Sunday.
“We expect that the track of Ernesto’s center will be well south of Nova Scotia as it travels northeastward then will approach southeastern Newfoundland later Monday,” the Canadian Hurricane Centre reports.
The forecast of Ernesto’s impact on Atlantic Canada now seems to focus more on Newfoundland and Labrador.
In Halifax, only slightly more than 5 mm of rain is forecast for early Monday, according to AccuWeather, with 32 km/h winds.
Feature image courtesy of the Canadian Hurricane Centre
event_breakdown: Hurricane Ernesto and its expected track.

title: Atlantic Ocean Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is now transitioning to the Caribbean Sea
message:
Atlantic Ocean’s Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is now transitioning to the Caribbean SeaArticle first published: Monday, July 01, 2024, 5 a.m.
Category 5 Hurricane Beryl's journey: it developed in the Atlantic Ocean, made its way to the Caribbean Sea.
Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is 445 miles east-southeast of Isla Beata Dominican Republic and 775 miles east-southeast of Kingston Jamaica, with maximum sustained wind of 165 mph.
A Tropical Storm Warning means that tropical storm conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area within 36 hours.
RAINFALL: Hurricane Beryl is expected to produce rainfall totals of 4 to 8 inches, with localized maxima of 12 inches, in portions of Jamaica on Wednesday.

title: Hurricane Ernesto bears down on Bermuda , already knocking out power
message:
Hurricane Ernesto bears down on Bermuda, already knocking out power3 minutesBy Jasmine Patterson and Nicola MuirheadBERMUDA (Reuters) -Hurricane Ernesto bore down on Bermuda on Friday as a Category 2 storm, threatening the British island territory with strong winds, a dangerous storm surge and potentially deadly flooding.
This storm is the real deal,” said Michael Weeks, Bermuda’s national security minister, at a press conference on Friday.
The winds had knocked out power for 5,400 of Bermuda’s 36,000 customers, the power utility BELCO said.
The island has experienced prolonged power outages in recent years when weather systems much more powerful than Ernesto rolled through.
Ernesto is the fifth named Atlantic storm of what is expected to be an intense hurricane season.

title: In the Caribbean : Bermuda braces for Hurricane Ernesto
message:
Bermuda is on high alert as residents brace for Hurricane Ernesto to make landfall on Friday.
In parts of Bermuda, Storm Ernesto will drop up to 380 mm of rain.
The National Hurricane Center warned of a strong storm surge and the risk of flash flooding.
The Bermuda government warned on X that the hurricane would hit the islands at 11 a.m. Saturday and asked residents to take precautions.
Earlier this week, Storm Ernesto passed close to Puerto Rico, leaving more than 600,000 people without power and flooding roads.

title: Hurricane Ernesto : Nova Scotia and eastern Newfoundland told to watch for big waves – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
HALIFAX – Residents of Nova Scotia and eastern Newfoundland are being told to keep a close watch on the progress of Hurricane Ernesto as it churns its way northward, pushing big waves far from its swirling centre.
As of Friday, the storm was expected to stay far to the south and east of Nova Scotia, but the Canadian Hurricane Centre in Dartmouth, N.S., said Ernesto could cause some coastal flooding in parts of eastern Newfoundland by Monday night.
This GOES-16 GeoColor satellite image taken at 4 p.m. EDT and provided by National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) shows Hurricane Ernesto northwest of San Juan, Puerto Rico and moving over open waters, Wednesday, Aug. 14, 2024.
On July 11, the remnants of hurricane Beryl flooded parts of western and central Nova Scotia with more than 100 millimetres of rain in just a few hours.
For a Category 2 hurricane, Ernesto is a large storm, with winds exceeding 120 km/h extending up to 110 kilometres from its centre.

title: Has recent rain helped S . C . farmers struggling from drought ?
message:
SAINT MATTHEWS, S.C. (WIS) — With drought conditions around the Palmetto State drastically improving following Debby last week, one farmer said the recent rain has been a mixed bag for his crops.
This week, the South Carolina Department of Natural Resources’ Drought Response Committee downgraded drought designations to normal for 36 counties.
The dry corn crop has been impacted by the double whammy brought forth by the drought and heavy rain from Debby, as well.
It was already nearly a total loss, but the rain has made it worse, Lyons said.
“Every time it rains it just adds more to that total,” Lyons said.

1. South Carolina: Following Debby, corn crops in critical condition 
2. South Carolina: Dust Storms Destroyed Crops, Livestock

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forms In Atlantic : Here 5 - Day Projected Path
message:
The projected timing and track of the tropical rainstorm through Friday evening, Aug. 16, is shown in the image above, just released late Monday by the National Hurricane Center.
The rainstorm is "forecast to intensify and bring heavy rainfall, gusty winds, and storm surge to parts of the Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, and the Dominican Republic this week," according to a statement by AccuWeather.com.
Formation chance through 48 hours is high at 70 percent and through seven days even higher at 90 percent, the National Hurricane Center said.
"After moving through the islands, the storm is forecast to be pulled to the north by a southward dip in the jet stream," AccuWeather Lead Hurricane Expert Alex DaSilva said.
"The storm may continue to intensify and could become the second major hurricane of the season by the end of this week."
event_breakdown:
1. Tropical storm Dorian is currently affecting the Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, and the Dominican Republic, with winds of 60 mph. The storm is expected to reach hurricane-strength later in the week.
2. Nepal is experiencing its worst monsoon floods in a decade, affecting 4.5 million people and killing at least 100 people (CNN).
3. Parts of India and Pakistan are facing a heat wave with temperatures over 120 degrees F, resulting in deaths and widespread power outages.

title: Ernesto will track south of the Maritimes on Monday
message:
Hurricane Ernesto will track well south of the Maritimes as it moves through the region on Sunday night and Monday.
A track this far south means that the heaviest rainfall and strongest winds will also remain offshore.
That said, Ernesto will be rather large and some of the outer bands of rain may edge into the Maritimes on Monday.
(Ryan Snoddon/CBC)With the track offshore, the risk of any wind impacts is low for the Maritimes.

title: Quebec widens scope of tropical storm Debby flooding compensation
message:
Quebec Premier François Legault said Friday afternoon that the province would now be compensating homes that were damaged by overflowing sewers as heavy rainfall caused by tropical storm Debby flooded hundreds of Quebec households.
Public Security Minister François Bonnardel joined Legault at the press briefing, updating the flooding cleanup situation as well as providing an update on flooding caused by a major water main break in south-central Montreal.
The water main break caused a geyser that lasted for hours Friday morning and was, at times, nearly as high as the nearby Jacques-Cartier Bridge.
WATCH | Water main break causes geyser near Jacques-Cartier Bridge: Water spews into Montreal streets after water main break Duration 0:33 Video captured Friday shows water bursting out of a ruptured main in downtown Montreal, near the Jacques-Cartier Bridge.
There were about 100 different places that were affected and I made the decision it would be more efficient to respond to the developing situation," Legault said.
event_breakdown:
Quebec flood cleanup
In an update Friday afternoon, Canadian Hydrographic Service water level specialist André Langlois said the river level at Trois-Pistoles had peaked.
Environment Canada ended a rainfall warning at 4 p.m., but residual rain was still expected throughout the night.

title: Highway 53 E in Pender County reopens after flooding
message:
Highway 53 E in Pender County reopens after floodingPENDER COUNTY, NC (WWAY) — After several days of being closed due to flooding from Tropical Storm Debby, Highway 53 East in Pender County reopened on Friday.
The roadway provides a vital link between Burgaw and eastern Pender County.
With the Northeast Cape Fear River cresting for the last several days, flooding persisted long after Debby made its way north.
Pender County Maintenance Engineer Jeff Garrett says even after water recedes, roads still have to be checked for safety.
Because even using the backroads, there’s flooding,” another resident said.

title: Harris County commissioners propose tax - hike for flood control maintenance
message:
The proposed $2.6 billion budget approved by Harris County commissioners includes a tax hike for flood control.
Years after taxpayers approved spending billion on flood mitigation effort, in response the Hurricane Harvey flooding, the county flood control district says it needs more money to keep those improvements in good working order.

title: Homes along the Suwannee River experiencing flooding 11 days post Hurricane Debby
message:
OLD TOWN, Fla. (WCJB) - The Crutchfields have been living along the Suwannee River for years and know what’s to come if there’s a storm.
They park their cars where the water meets the road and take a boat to their home.
“We knew what the Suwannee would do and as we have been here we’ve learned okay what to do.
Tie the picnic table down or it will float away.”Crutchfield says they’ve seen flooding much worse than it is now.

event_breakdown:
Hurricane Ernesto lashes Bermuda, Typhoon Lekima hits China, and flooding in Assam
Hurricane Ernesto lashed Bermuda with heavy rains and strong winds early Saturday as it neared the British Atlantic Ocean territory, with meteorologists warning of a dangerous storm surge and floods. The storm was expected to pass near or over Bermuda in the next few hours.

"A dangerous storm surge is expected to produce significant coastal flooding on Bermuda in areas of onshore winds," the National Hurricane Center said. Ernesto was expected to dump 5 to 10 inches of rain on Bermuda, with isolated maximum amounts of 15 inches, the center said. The center warned residents to stay indoors. No evacuations were ordered, but some residents remained on alert.

The hurricane was centered about 200 miles southeast of Bermuda on Saturday afternoon, moving northward at 6 mph. At one point on Friday, it had grown into a Category 4 storm, with maximum sustained winds of 130 mph. But the storm weakened to a Category 1 storm as it headed toward Bermuda, with maximum sustained winds of 85 mph.

Ernesto was about 475 miles south-southeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, on Saturday and was moving slowly northward. The center said the storm was expected to weaken further by Friday night, with winds diminishing to a tropical storm by Saturday night.

message:

Swells generated by Ernesto were already affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

title: Hurricane Ernesto weakens , but still dangerous , as it closes in on Bermuda
message:
Hurricane Ernesto weakens, but still dangerous, as it closes in on BermudaBy Jasmine Patterson and Nicola MuirheadBERMUDA (Reuters) - Hurricane Ernesto was weakening as it closed in on Bermuda early on Saturday, downgraded to a Category 1 storm but still threatening the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge and potentially deadly flooding.
Its slow speed - moving north-northeast at 13 mph (20 kph) - and large size means Bermuda could experience a lengthy pummeling on Saturday night, the hurricane center said.
While it may continue to weaken for the next day or so, it is forecast to strengthen again over the Gulf Stream, the hurricane center said.
Rainfall on Bermuda was forecast at up to 9 inches (225 mm), the hurricane center said.
Swells generated by Ernesto were already affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

title: Tropical Storm Ernesto Forms In Atlantic : Here 5 - Day Projected Path

The projected timing and track of the tropical rainstorm through Friday evening, Aug. 16, is shown in the image above, just released late Monday by the National Hurricane Center.
The rainstorm is "forecast to intensify and bring heavy rainfall, gusty winds, and storm surge to parts of the Lesser Antilles, Puerto Rico, and the Dominican Republic this week," according to a statement by AccuWeather.com.
Formation chance through 48 hours is high at 70 percent and through seven days even higher at 90 percent, the National Hurricane Center said.

"The storm may continue to intensify and could become the second major hurricane of the season by the end of this week."

In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory suspended public transportation and closed the airport on Friday night.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has predicted an above-average Atlantic hurricane season this year because of record warm ocean temperatures.

event_breakdown: Tropical storm is pounding Bermuda Details * Ernesto, the fifth named storm * Third hurricane * Officials say it has maximum sustained winds of 100 mph * Ernesto is continuing to pound Bermuda Friday night, though it wasn't expected to be a direct hit. It's able to make that close approach because it's gradually weakening -- losing its distinction as a hurricane. Forecasters expect it to weaken further to a tropical storm as it heads toward Nova Scotia on Saturday, but it still could drop 2 to 4 inches of rain over eastern New England on Sunday. For Bermuda, the center of Ernesto is expected to pass to its east Friday night and Saturday morning. Everyone in Bermuda was urged to stay indoors. (Source: CNN)

In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory suspended public transportation and closed the airport on Friday night.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has predicted an above-average Atlantic hurricane season this year because of record warm ocean temperatures.

message:

"There is 1-1/2 persons that work in this department: me full time and Bill Minikiewicz (former director of emergency services)) is part-time now."
Bamberg CountyBamberg County Director of Emergency Services Tiffany Kemmerlin began her career in emergency services in 2012 when she joined the Edisto Fire Department.
"During those years, I grew a passion for emergency management and accepted an administrative assistant position with Bamberg County Emergency Services," Kemmerlin said.
"Bamberg County Emergency Services remains vigilant in preparing for an active hurricane season," she said.

title: Hurricane Ernesto brings impacts to Bermuda through Saturday evening
message:
(WTOK) -Bermuda gets the full blow of Ernesto through Saturday evening as it moves very near if not directly over the Island.
It’s going to slow down a bit while impacting Bermuda because it’ll lack a good steering flow for just a little while.
Yet, by Sunday, it’ll get a kick towards the NE...and out to sea it goes while eventually loosing its tropical characteristics into next week.
Impacts from flooding rain and damaging hurricane force winds are expected for Bermuda.
Behind Ernesto, we’re currently not tracking any other tropical waves, Yet, we’re getting closer to the peak of the season.

title: More than a dozen states grappled with  flash drought  this summer here what that means for farmers
message:
More than a dozen states grappled with 'flash drought' this summer — here's what that means for farmersAt least 15 states in the eastern U.S. were affected by various degrees of drought entering the first week of August.
In some cases, the drought came on quickly; some areas experienced a "flash drought."
A recent study found that the intensity of flash droughts is increasing worldwide.
Another study said flash droughts will double because of the changing climate of our warming world.
More than 86 million acres of major crops were also experiencing drought conditions.

title: Over 100 people apply for storm relief in Steuben County
message:
CANISTEO, N.Y. (WETM) — More than a hundred Steuben County residents are seeking recovery help from the damages inflicted by Tropical Storm Debby.
People were able to file for relief during a three-day flood relief resource event held this week at three locations in Canisteo, Greenwood, and Woodhull.
Jacqueline Saunders a flood victim of Pulteney, stated that she has damaged equipment, lost personal items, and has mud in her house.
Tropical Storm Debby is the second storm in three years that is impacting local communities since Tropical Storm Fred in 2021.
Steuben County Director of Public Safety Timothy Marshall thinks that the infrastructure damage from Debby is worse than Fred.
event_breakdown: Tropical Storm Debby (Over eastern U.S.)}

title: First responders warn of rough surf , rip currents at beaches this weekend
message:
First responders warn of rough surf, rip currents at beaches this weekendMIDDLETOWN, R.I. (WPRI) — Hurricane Ernesto, which is currently churning through the Atlantic Ocean, is expected to bring rough surf to local beaches this weekend.
He described the waters as being calm, though he acknowledged that the storm is well on its way.
Though the storm isn’t expected to hit the Northeast directly, it is expected to create big waves and strong rip currents at local beaches.
Battalion Chief Brian Defreitas, director of EMS at the Middletown Fire Department, told 12 News his team will be assisting nearly 40 lifeguards at town beaches this weekend.
“Hopefully we don’t have a busy weekend, but if we are needed, we’re here and we’re staffed,” Defreitas said.
event_breakdown:
Hurricane Ernesto (location: Atlantic Ocean, near coast of North America)
Rough surf and rip currents are expected at local beaches in Middletown, Rhode Island.

title: Hurricane Ernesto hits Bermuda as a weakened but still dangerous storm
message:
By Jasmine Patterson and Nicola MuirheadBERMUDA (Reuters) -Hurricane Ernesto made landfall on Bermuda early on Saturday and was expected to batter the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge and potentially deadly flooding.
Ernesto was carrying top sustained winds of 85 mph (140 kph) the U.S. National Hurricane Center said, although it had weakened to a Category 1 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale as it approached.
Ernesto was expected to slowly depart Bermuda during Saturday, moving north-northeast on a track that would take it near or east of Newfoundland on Monday night, the hurricane center said.
The storm was carrying a dangerous storm surge that was expected to produce significant coastal flooding in parts of Bermuda, while rainfall was forecast at up to 9 inches (225 mm), the center said.
Little change in its current strength was expected during Saturday, although some re-intensification was possible late in the weekend before weakening begins on Monday, the hurricane center said.
event_breakdown: Ernesto (Category 1 Hurricane) is currently battering Bermuda with powerful winds and dangerous storm surge, while heavy rainfall is causing potential flooding.

title: Hurricane Ernesto makes landfall on Bermuda as a category 1 storm with 85 mph winds
message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto made landfall on the tiny British Atlantic territory of Bermuda early Saturday as residents hunkered down.
The wide category 1 storm was directly over the wealthy territory at 6 a.m. Saturday, with maximum sustained winds of 85 mph (140 kph).
The U.S. National Hurricane Center warned of strong winds, a dangerous storm surge and significant coastal flooding.
Bermuda power utility BELCO said that as of late Friday, power was out to 31% of its customers.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.

Tropical Storm Ernesto
A Category 2 storm located 95 miles south-southwest of Bermuda late Friday afternoon was packing maximum sustained winds of 100 mph, making it a strong but thankfully far from catastrophic storm for Bermuda.
Ernesto’s large eye will likely be near or over Bermuda early Saturday morning, with significant coastal flooding expected, according to the National Hurricane Center. It was also warned that tropical-storm-force winds could arrive on Bermuda through Saturday morning. The hurricane center forecast Friday evening said erratic fluctuations in strength are possible through Saturday night, but not a significant weakening in strength, while the Bermuda Weather Service warns that the storm could be more powerful than Hurricane Irma of 2017.
In preparation for the storm, officials in the wealthy British territory suspended public transportation and closed the airport on Friday night.

title: Thousands without power as Ernesto makes landfall in Bermuda
message:
Hurricane Ernesto lashed Bermuda with heavy rains and strong winds early Saturday, leaving much of the British Atlantic Ocean territory without power as it made landfall, with meteorologists warning of a dangerous storm surge and floods.
"A dangerous storm surge is expected to produce significant coastal flooding on Bermuda in areas of onshore winds.
Ernesto was expected to dump six to nine inches (150 to 225 millimeters) of rain on Bermuda.
"This is not a storm to be taken lightly," he said, warning islanders to expect 36 hours of hurricane-force winds.
Ernesto was moving northeast and expected to slowly depart Bermuda Saturday and move near or east of Newfoundland in eastern Canada on Monday night, the NHC said.
event_breakdown: Bermuda, Canada

message:
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto made landfall on the tiny British Atlantic territory of Bermuda early Saturday as residents hunkered down.
The wide category 1 storm was directly over the the wealthy territory at 6 a.m.SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto made landfall on the tiny British Atlantic territory of Bermuda early Saturday as residents hunkered down.
The U.S. National Hurricane Center warned of strong winds, a dangerous storm surge and significant coastal flooding.
Bermuda power utility BELCO said that as of late Friday, power was out to 31% of its customers.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.
event_breakdown:
1. A wildfire in and around Mt. Baldy, Angeles National Forest, is overflowing containment lines and threatening nearby communities. The fire has blown up to 2,500 acres and is only 5% contained, sending up a massive plume of smoke that is visible throughout the Los Angeles Basin.
2. Hurricane Olivia made landfall in Hawaii this morning, the first hurricane to strike the state in 22 years. It came ashore on the Leeward coast, striking the Big Island, and immediately brought torrential rain and dangerous flash floods.
3. Winter storm warnings and winter weather advisories have been issued for the Northeast as a major storm moves into the region, bringing heavy snow to the heart of the Northeast, with accumulations of 3 to 6 inches expected for the Boston area.
4. Debris flows and mudslides have occurred in southern California following heavy rain. Evacuation orders for burn areas have been issued in response to the storms.
5. Tropical Storm Julian exists of the East coast of Mexico. It is expected to produce 3 to 6 inches of rain across the Mexican states of Campeche, Chiapas, Quintana Roo, Tabasco and Yucatan. In addition to rain, the storm could potentially produce life-threatening flash floods and mudslides.
6. Typhoon Wutip - this severe tropical-weather event happened a few days ago so its news no longer current.
7. Peru has declared a state of emergency after at least 72 people in Peru were killed as a result of torrential rains and overflowing rivers caused by remnants of Former Hurricane Willa.

message:

AdvertAs it happened under the water, it caused a tsunami of ocean waves that devastated many nearby countries.

title: Students tackle flooding with storm drain markers
message:
I'll show how local efforts, like the storm drain marker program, are keeping our streets safe and water clean.
Over the past year and a half, students in Thomas County have installed over 350 storm drain markers to help prevent flooding and protect local waterways.
Julie Murphee, founder of Keep Thomas County Beautiful, tells me storm water is one of the main concerns for Thomas County.
"storm water is a leading cause of water pollution.
Jay Knight, construction supervisor at Thomas County, tells me they've been building retention ponds to manage stormwater.

title: Tropical Storm Debby eases drought in NC
message:
Following Tropical Storm Debby last week, most of North Carolina has been cleared of drought or dry conditions, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor’s latest weekly update.
The update shows that Winston-Salem has moved out of the D1 (moderate drought) category, while Greensboro is no longer classified as D0 (abnormally dry).
The Triad region is now categorized as having “none” of dry or drought conditions.
The development also marks the first time since June 18 that both cities have been free from any dry or drought conditions.
Tropical Storm Debby prompted a state of emergency in North Carolina, bringing heavy rainfall and widespread power outages across the state.

title: Atlantic Ocean Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is now transitioning to the Caribbean Sea
message:

Category 5 Hurricane Beryl's journey: it developed in the Atlantic Ocean, made its way to the Caribbean Sea.
Category 5 Hurricane Beryl is 445 miles east-southeast of Isla Beata Dominican Republic and 775 miles east-southeast of Kingston Jamaica, with maximum sustained wind of 165 mph.

title: Hurricane Ernesto makes landfall in Bermuda as residents hunker down
message:
Bermuda minister warns third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season ‘is not a storm to be taken lightly’.
Hurricane Ernesto has left tens of thousands of people without power across Bermuda as it hit the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge and potentially deadly flooding.
Ernesto was expected to slowly depart Bermuda over the course of the day, according to the National Hurricane Center (NHC) in the United States.
Strong Winds, dangerous storm surge, and life-threatening flooding expected to continue on Bermuda today.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.

title: Hurricane Ernesto moves through Bermuda as a category 1 storm
message:
MEXICO CITY (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto which made landfall on the tiny British Atlantic territory of Bermuda early Saturday was downgraded to a tropical storm by afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Earlier, the U.S. National Hurricane Center warned of strong winds, a dangerous storm surge and significant coastal flooding.
Due to the large size of the storm and its slow movement, tropical storm force winds and gusts to hurricane force are expected to continue through Saturday afternoon, with tropical storm-strength winds continuing well into Sunday, the Bermuda government said.
The Bermuda Weather Service confirmed the passage of the eye was from 5:30 am to 8:30 am local time in Bermuda.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.

It was expected to maintain its current intensity for another 48 hours, after which it should weaken, the U.S. weather service said.

title: Hurricane Ernesto Hits Bermuda as a Weakened But Still Dangerous Storm
message:
TEMPO.CO, Bermuda - Hurricane Ernesto landed on Bermuda early on Saturday, August 17, and was expected to batter the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge, and potentially deadly flooding.
Ernesto was carrying top sustained winds of 85 mph (140 kph) the U.S. National Hurricane Center said.
However, it had weakened to a Category 1 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale as it approached.
Ernesto was expected to slowly depart Bermuda on Saturday, moving north-northeast on a track that would take it near or east of Newfoundland on Monday night, the hurricane center said.
Ocean swells generated by Ernesto were affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

title: Earthquake scientists are learning warning signs of  The Big One . When should they tell the public ?
message:
COPALIS BEACH, WASH. — When Japan issued its first-ever “megaquake” warning last week, Harold Tobin, Washington state’s seismologist, was watching carefully.
Rather, seismologists were concerned that the quake would create stress that could trigger a bomb ticking offshore: Japan’s Nankai trough, likely the country’s most dangerous fault.
Police stand outside a damaged building following an earthquake in Miyazaki, western Japan, on Aug. 8.
Kyodo News via AP fileIn the U.S., Tobin said, “we don’t have such a protocol.”We do, however, have a similarly dangerous fault: the Cascadia subduction zone.
A magnitude-9.0 earthquake on the Cascadia fault and the resulting tsunami would kill an estimated 14,000 people in Oregon and Washington, according to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
